sols_html:
The two curves will intersect at \(x = 3\) if their y-values are the same at \(x = 3\). To find the y-values, we just plug \(x = 3\) into each curve.

The first curve gives:

\[\begin{aligned} y &= \frac16 \sqrt{2(3)^2 + 7} \\ &= \frac16 \sqrt{25} \\ &= \frac56 \end{aligned}\]

The second curve gives:

\[\begin{aligned} y &= -2(3)^2 + 7(3) -\frac{13}{6}\\ &= -18 + 21 -\frac{13}{6}\\ &= 3 -\frac{13}{6}\\ &= \frac{18}{6} -\frac{13}{6} \\ &= \frac56 \end{aligned}\]

These two y-values are equal, so the curves do intersect at \(x = 3\).

statement_html:
Two curves are said to intersect orthogonally at x =a if (i) they intersect at x = a and (ii) their tangent lines are perpendicular at x = a.

Verify that the curves \(y = \frac16 \sqrt{2x^2+7}\) and \(y = -2x^2 + 7x -\frac{13}{6}\) intersect at \(x = 3\).
